Authors:
Kira Mary Theresa Lynn, Michael J Wingfield, Alvaro Duran,
Z. Wilhelm de Beer, Leonardo Sarno Soares Oliveira, Irene Barnes
Title:
Novel Fusarium associates of two Euwallacea species infesting
Acacia crassicarpa in Indonesia
Keywords:
Ambrosia beetles · Fusarium · Euwallacea symbiosis · 5 new
taxa
Abstract:
Several species in the Euwallacea fornicatus complex have
emerged as important pests of woody plants globally, particularly in
habitats where they are invasive aliens. These beetles live in obligate
symbioses with fungi in the genus Fusarium. In this study, we identified
Euwallacea spp. and their fungal associates that have emerged as pests
of planted Acacia crassicarpa in Riau, Indonesia. Morphological
identification and phylogenetic analyses of the mitochondrial cytochrome
oxidase c subunit I (COI) gene, confirmed that E. similis and E.
perbrevis are the most abundant beetles infesting these trees.
Multi-locus phylogenetic analyses of their fungal associates revealed
their non-specific association with six Fusarium spp. These included F.
rekanum and five novel members of the Ambrosia Fusarium Clade (AFC).
These new speceis are described here as F. akasia, F. awan, F. mekan, F.
variasi and F. warna.
